cost_objections.objection: Your pricing is higher than I expected / We have a limited budget
cost_objections.poor_response: You get what you pay for / We're worth it
cost_objections.authentic_response: I understand budget is tight - let me show you exactly where your investment goes and what happens without proper planning. Most of our clients find that our fee is 2-3% of their total event budget, but we help them avoid the 15-20% cost overruns that happen when details are missed. We can also discuss a phased approach where we handle the highest-risk elements first and you manage other pieces internally.
cost_objections.reframe: The real cost isn't our fee - it's what a failed event costs your organization's reputation, member retention, and next year's attendance. We're insurance against expensive mistakes.

diy_objection.objection: I think I can handle this myself / We have an internal team
diy_objection.poor_response: No you can't / You'll regret it
diy_objection.authentic_response: You absolutely might be able to - especially if someone on your team has done events of this scale before. Here's what I'd suggest: let's walk through your planning checklist together right now. I'll point out the 8-10 areas where I see first-time planners hit problems, and you can decide if those are risks you're comfortable managing. Many clients work with us just on the complex pieces like AV, vendor negotiations, or day-of coordination while handling registration and content themselves.
diy_objection.reframe: This isn't about whether you're capable - it's about whether this is the best use of your time and whether the learning curve is worth the risk for this particular event.

timing_objection.objection: We're not ready to commit yet / We need to think about it
timing_objection.poor_response: You need to decide now / This offer expires
timing_objection.authentic_response: I completely understand - this is a significant decision. What specific information do you still need to feel confident? I can tell you that the main thing that changes with time is your available options. Right now you have full choice of venues, vendors, and dates. In two months, you'll be choosing from what's left. I'm happy to hold a planning slot for you for [X days] while you finalize your decision, but I want to be transparent that we do have other events booking for that timeframe.
timing_objection.reframe: The decision you're making isn't just about hiring us - it's about when to start serious planning. Every week that passes is a week less to create something great.

trust_objection.objection: How do I know you'll actually deliver / I've been burned before
trust_objection.poor_response: Just trust us / Look at our reviews
trust_objection.authentic_response: That's a completely fair concern, and I'm sorry you had a bad experience. Here's how we're different: [Specific process like weekly check-ins, shared project management access, milestone-based payments, named point person]. I'd like you to speak with [specific past client name] who had a similar concern - they can tell you exactly how we handled challenges during their event. We also include [specific guarantee or protection] in our contract so you have recourse if we don't perform.
trust_objection.reframe: Trust is earned through transparency. Let me show you our entire process, introduce you to your actual team, and give you complete visibility into how we work before you commit.

scope_objection.objection: We only need help with [small piece] not full planning
scope_objection.poor_response: You need to hire us for everything
scope_objection.authentic_response: That's totally fine - we offer day-of coordination, partial planning, and full-service options. Let me ask you a few questions about your event to make sure [small piece] is actually the only gap. Sometimes what looks like just an AV issue is actually a symptom of broader planning needs. If you truly only need [specific service], I'll quote you just that. If I see other risks, I'll point them out and you can decide what to tackle.
scope_objection.reframe: Our job is to help you identify and address risks, not to sell you services you don't need. Let's figure out the right level of support together.

comparison_objection.objection: We're talking to other planners / getting multiple bids
comparison_objection.poor_response: We're the best / Don't waste your time
comparison_objection.authentic_response: You should absolutely talk to multiple planners - this is too important a decision to make without comparison. Here's what I'd suggest looking for: ask each planner about a time something went wrong during an event and how they handled it. Ask for references from events similar to yours in size and industry. And pay attention to whether they're asking you questions or just pitching services. When you're ready to compare, I'm happy to walk through any questions about our proposal.
comparison_objection.reframe: The right planner for you is someone whose experience, communication style, and approach matches your needs - and you can't know that without talking to a few options.

The reality:
• 2x the production cost
• Mediocre experience for both audiences
• Virtual attendees don't convert to in-person

• Virtual attendance: 40% of in-person
• Virtual engagement: <15% watch live
• Virtual ticket price: 20-30% of in-person
• Virtual attendee return rate: 8%

The math doesn't work.

3/ The real problem:

You're trying to serve two completely different audiences with one event

In-person = experience, networking, immersion
Virtual = convenience, content, flexibility

These are incompatible goals.

4/ What works instead:

OPTION A: All in-person + recorded content library
• Premium in-person experience
• Recordings as post-event value
• No compromise on either

OPTION B: Separate virtual & in-person events
• Different content
• Different pricing
• Different outcomes

5/ The exception:

Hybrid works if:
• You have 1,000+ attendees
• Dedicated virtual production team
• Different content for each audience
• Budget for both experiences

Most don't meet this criteria.

6/ What we recommend:

Invest in making in-person EXCEPTIONAL
Use virtual for:
• Pre-event education
• Post-event implementation
• Year-round community

Not as a poor substitute for being there.

7/ Bottom line:

Your attendees would rather have one great experience than two mediocre ones.

Stop trying to be everything to everyone.

6/ The real skill? Telling clients 'no' in a way that leads to 'yes' - to the RIGHT solution.
7/ We found them a perfect 6,000 sq ft venue with breakout options. Cost less, worked better, everyone happy.
Moral: Convention planning is problem-solving with physics, logistics, and human behavior. Hire someone who knows the difference.

Sponsors budget annually. If you approach them mid-year, their money's already allocated.

Launch 10-12 months out. Early revenue = better cash flow = better event.

Event cancellation, liability, weather - all require advance planning and better rates with time.

7/ VENDOR CONTRACTS
A/V, catering, decorators - the good ones book fast. Waiting means settling for second-tier.

8/ MARKETING STRATEGY
Build anticipation over months, not weeks. Social media algorithms reward consistency.

9/ CONTINGENCY PLANS
What if your venue floods? Speaker cancels? Pandemic 2.0? Plan B needs as much time as Plan A.

The pattern? Everything good requires lead time.

Convention planning isn't about working hard for 3 months. It's about working smart for 12+.

Sunday 5pm: Event feedback rolling in. 4.6/5 rating. Higher than last year.

7/ 🚩 Cancellation policy heavily favors the venue

Force majeure clauses, non-refundable deposits, penalties for reducing numbers. Read the fine print CAREFULLY.

BONUS 🚩: Sales team is pushy but operations team is impossible to reach.

You're not marrying the salesperson. You're working with ops. Meet them before signing.

Most conventions are designed for organizers, not attendees.

Here's how we flip that: 🧵

Standard convention:
- Registration 8am (people groggy)
- Sessions back-to-back (no processing time)
- Lunch = networking (exhausting)
- Exhibitor hall during breaks (overwhelming)

We do it differently:

ARRIVAL EXPERIENCE:
- Pre-registration online (skip lines)
- Welcome lounge with coffee 7-8am
- Chill music, comfortable seating
- No 'networking pressure'

People arrive relaxed, not stressed.

SESSION DESIGN:
- 45-min sessions (not 60)
- 30-min breaks (not 15)
- Designated 'quiet zones' for introverts
- Clear signage with session difficulty levels

People choose what fits them.

FOOD STRATEGY:
- Continuous grazing stations (not fixed lunch time)
- Dietary options clearly labeled
- Seating for 60% of attendees (not 100%)
- Some standing tables for quick bites

People eat when hungry, not when scheduled.

EXHIBITOR HALL:
- Dedicated 2-hour block (not 'during breaks')
- Scavenger hunt gamification
- Lounge areas inside hall
- Lower music/stimulation than typical

People actually engage instead of rushing through.

NETWORKING:
- Structured activities for those who want it
- Opt-in badge ribbons ('Open to connect')
- Topic-based meetup spots
- Solo attendee welcome session

People connect authentically.

ENERGY MANAGEMENT:
- No sessions after 4pm (brain is done)
- Optional evening social (not mandatory gala)
- Wellness room with massage chairs, quiet space
- Next-day schedule released night before

People leave energized, not drained.

FEEDBACK LOOP:
- Real-time session ratings via app
- Adjustment capability for Day 2/3
- Post-event survey with actual changes made
- Share results publicly

People feel heard.

The result?
- 4.7/5 average satisfaction (industry avg: 3.8)
- 68% return rate (industry avg: 42%)
- 2x more positive social mentions
- Easier to sell tickets next year

Attendee-first design isn't just nice. It's smart business.
